you don't have to explain to me, cause I am pretty sure gonna delete this game after I finish writing this.
Second. game provide 3 servers that EU, NA, SA. which their ping follows 270, 270, 323.

I am talking about computer bot match mod. after tutorial failed to deliver its intended function and pissed me off. As a final result what you see on screen is enemy is moving smoothly on time while every your movement is lagged 1 second after you pressed the key.  
there you goes, the game that even playing with bot is unplayable is complete.
Game's bgm is somewhat nice to listen while I am writing this.

author: {'steamid': '76561199125395547', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 99, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 99, 'last_played': 1650213003}
review:
A game I wanna love but lots of things holding it back.

The game is one of those simple to play, hard to master. Based on Ping Pong it must be pretty simple right? Wrong. Instead of being able to hit the Pong with only the stick it now has to be hit by being blasted by power blast from your ship. It has borders to stop the blast from the other player but not completely. With the addition of characters, different ships which changes the type of powers you use, how big your blast is, if you have shields, how long it takes to charge etc.

So, now that the basic's is out the way how does it feel to play? Very smoothly when its not lagging. You can play local, VS AI, Online or Ranked Online. In the start your going to play VS AI since the online is locked behind lvls. Playing vs the AI is odd for one major reason...IT FREAKING LAGS AND IS ONLINE? Why does playing against AI make you lag so bad to where you can't even move up or down? I suggest changing this ASAP cause its very obnoxious in the middle of a heated exchange. Moving on the online its sad cause from what I saw this game is DEAD. The player base while writing this is sadly very small to the point where it took me 40 minutes to look for a single match in which I gave up at that point.  Also while I was training and waiting for a match it was NOT LAGGING AT ALL. Whatever you did for that you should do for the AI matches.

Conclusion: The gameplay while the best part of this game is heavily held back by the lack of a player base most likely due too the constant lagging in a match which stops you from moving in your tracks.
Gameplay: 5/5 (Simple but really fun gameplay)
Graphics: 4/5 (Great art style on really high graphics) 
Soundtrack: 1/5 (Got annoying very quickly)
Online: 0/5 (Dead player base due to constant lag)
Total: 2/5 (Has potential if the lag is fixed, which may bring a stable player base)

Will be looking forward to any updates if the lag is fixed until then I DO not recommend this game.

D√®s que la balle touche le mur adverse le joueur r√©cup√®re un point, le premier qui en obtient trois gagne le set.

review:
Fun pong-style PVP or AI battles, decently thought out mechanics, great art & style, and it's literally free. 
Give it a try.

That said, input lag (but is actually server side movement, not input lag) (even on US servers close to me) isn't acceptable for a competitive game - and that's not the fault of the ping itself. The way the netcode is done (from what I can gather), means that you see the game as what server side says it is, when in every major competitive game right now, your own perspective is determined client side: it's literally the only way to make netcode that feels playable. Even at something like 50 ping, you're visually waiting 100ms before you see your ship move. The total effect of this problem? You must input in advance of what you think will happen, else you're playing 100-150ms behind (situationally). The current system for netcode is literally impossible to make competitive or acceptable imo - there must be a change to client side movement & something like rollback netcode, or there will always feel like there's delay

TL/DR -Online matchmaking has very few players
           -Online matchmaking has connection issues with input delay
           -Ranked mode has people picking the same pilot and ship because its the best one

           -Keep in mind its a free to play game as well as fairly new the writing of this post so if

author: {'steamid': '76561198084711068', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 150, 'last_played': 1644215031}
review:
This game takes the basic aspects of a air hockey or pong game and turns them into a more action packed game of strategy and skill, leaving it closer to something like Lethal League. If you're looking for a high paced game of rallies or just something fun to pass a few minutes away, I highly recommend checking it out. If nothing else, it only takes a couple mins to download and a couple more to try. 

Pros: 
- Short game times (2-5 mins)
- Fast que times
- High intensity
- Fast learning curve, high skill ceiling
- Customizable to suit your playstyle 
- Excellent and fitting music
- Active developers
- Competitive or casual play options
- Bright but not distracting animation
- Local and private matches available

Cons:
- Lack of tutorial
- Matchmaking balance*

*You're going to go against people who've played before, some who are very skilled. Try to emulate their actions and focus on improvement before giving up after a few losses. The controls are simple enough that you're only limited by your patience to adapt and learn. 

Many complaints I've seen address finding a match or the game being confusing. The player base for this game is currently growing, but despite this, I've personally had no problems finding a game within a few seconds. All the mechanics of the game are shown, although they are not stated in a tutorial. Here are some basic mechanics of the game to alleviate confusion:

Game mechanics:
- Controls: Move up/down and fire (Keyboard: Arrow keys and Spacebar, Controller: Left stick and A). You can hold fire for a stronger shot, strength and charge speed are dependent on ship and pilot. 
- Objective: Get the ball through the opposite goal
- Scoring: Each round is first to 3 points, first to two rounds wins (in casual, in competitive it's first to 3). Mid-round points are shown center screen, round points are shown at the top.
- Shield: If you're hit by the ball at a fast enough speed, you'll lose 1 shield charge. Shields can regenerate, unlike health.  (Shield icons are located next to your character showing how many you have left, as well as a representation of your shield strength around your character)
- Health: If you have no shields, you will take health damage. Run out of this and you'll be destroyed, unable to defend your  goal. (Health is shown at the top of the screen)
- Ball speed: When the ball is hit by larger shots, it moves faster. Faster balls hit shields and health harder.

Summary:
This game is a fast paced, easy to learn, high skill ceiling game that you can use to fill a few mins or a several hours as casually or competitively as you like. 
I hope this review convinced you to try the game for yourself, and I'll to see you in the tower.

review:
Fun little game. It's a simple premise and doesn't let number crunching or side things get in the way of letting the core gameplay shine.  

I wish some of the stats were more explicitly explained so you can have an easier time finding the character and ship that fit best for your style.  That said, you get the general feel of things with a few rounds against a bot. Including a brief cheat-sheet detailing the mechanics and stats somewhere in the menu would be an easy fix.  

Where the game really excels is presentation.  It's got style.  The art, music and even the scoreboard and other HUD elements really contribute to the experience and those little things are what can set a game apart. 

Hopefully it gets a bigger player base, the price is certainly hard to argue with and potato rigs aren't a limiter either.  I look forward to trying to suck in a few friends. Give it a go.

review:
I played this game occasionally online with my friends and i found it to be very competitive. There were still some things to tweak and some lag to adjust. For example it lacked fluidity in the movement and i found no way to exit the game if not pressing x after alt plus enter. 
The recent update was shocking because the game losts its already precarious fluidity completely.
The shield is always on and cannot be broken anymore. 
Now i'll say some subjective opinions. Personally i preferred the old design, it was more clear in what was possible to do and what not, and by the look of a ship it was easier to get what they actually do.
One more specific opinion is the fact that this game is more about the match itself than the preparation, i already found it odd that you can upgrade a ship in the older version before a match, since we didn't want to have an unfair match we didn't upgrade any ship for making it less confusing. 
So in this game i don't find it necessary to have a campaign or anything like that, it has a feel of an old lan game party or like an hair hockey match. So a match should be always be balanced.
I hope this review wasn't too harsh, it appears that lots of works was put in this new update and i still find that the basic concept behind it is a smart way to make a simp,e pong much more competitive.
I hope it will get better.
developer_response:
How did I mess this review? Shame on me.

Anyway thanks for this review it is very clear and understandable.
We had some huge bugs on the 0.3 on release and maybe you noticed most of them have been fixed.

About the online feeling, it is because we changed how the algorythm work because previously: if you had the feeling of being smooth, the reality was different and your real position was probably somewhere else (because of the lag) this made some very weird feeling for players with a bad connection and we decided to move to this new sync system, like most of the games.

It is maybe more laggy (as feeling) but also more realistic (about time I mean).

Also we added a server in USA so make sure to uncheck servers you don't want to play on from the settings menu (there is also the ping displayed in game now).


About the readability of ships, we think that it will takes some times to players to know each modules and being able to read what the opponent get and do.

About the balance it is harder to do with this system, but we think in the long term it will bring more freedom in the gameplay of each players.

Ah final point, if you are not on the discord feel free to join it, it is faster/easier to talk with us and give us feedback like that, about how we can improve things and fix bugs faster.

Thanks for the time and the feedback, hopefully you will think it is better in the coming update and this review will go from bad to good üòä

review:
I download every single free-to-play, freemium, demo, and even some occasionally buy-to-play and subscription based MMOs I come across on Steam. This title, despite being in early testing, is one of the most enjoyable I've come across in the past few months. The controls are responsive, the ball physics are mostly spot-on, and it is one of the few iterations of Pong that changes the game in a way that adds new challenge to an old concept while not breaking it or just adding extra gimmicks. The AI difficulty ranges from lousy to a decent challenge and the playerbase -- albeit small -- is full of great people. No obvious pay-to-win items either. The artstyle is simplistic yet quite visually appealing. The music fits perfectly and is listenable outside of the game on it's own merit.

Highly recommended if you enjoy classic games, want a multiplayer game that isn't resource intensive, and don't want to be forced to grind for days on end in a multiplayer game just to be competitive. Skill wins out in this title but even when losing, it's still a blast.

review: Absolutely horrible. I don't know how you butcher such a simple concept so badly. This is pong, yet somehow the controls are confusing. It could just be the lag because for some reason the game responds to controller input really slowly so maybe my shots are just so far behind the actual button presses that it's creating a complete disconnect between my inputs and the actual action. The only other player in the game has a firm grasp on it however so he keeps beating the ever loving crap out of me. This game concept was already perfected 50 years ago, all you had to do was put a coat of polish on it and market it with a basic level of competence. How you screw that up is beyond me.

review:
interesting technical challenge. 

the game is not revolutionary by any means, yet the technical part of it is something worth looking into. 
It is full javascript, which means the game can be loaded in seconds and if for some bug or unforeseen trouble, the servers crashes, it took only seconds to restart everything. 

it still needs polish here and there, the interface for example is still work in progress.
the music is fine, not too repetitive, for me at least.

I wonder if more moves could be added down the line, a la "windjammers" otherwise the game loop is rather short.
Overall it has the same strength and weaknesses as a game of puck, it is fine for a few games but finding more depth will be a challenge. I'm looking forward to seeing how they manage that issue. I would recommend it 100% for the technical interest and for a short session of virtual puck.
